definitions.definition: the top inside surface of a room

examples.text: a large room with a **high ceiling**
The **walls and ceiling** were painted white.
A large chandelier **hangs from the ceiling**.
The ceiling of her room was low.
She lay on her back staring up at the ceiling.
The bathroom has mirrors from ceiling to floor.
The palace is famous for its 17th-century painted ceilings.

definitions.definition: the highest limit or amount of something

examples.text: The government has decided to lift price ceilings on bread and milk.
The reality is the economy is **hitting the ceiling** and the growth rate must slow.
They've put a $50 ceiling on their admission charge.
They have put a ceiling on the price of petrol.

definitions.definition: the greatest height at which a particular aircraft is able to fly

examples.text: an aircraft with a ceiling of 20 000 feet

wordOrigin: Middle English (denoting the action of lining the interior of a room with plaster or panelling): from ceil (perhaps related to Latin celare, French céler ‘conceal’) + -ing. Sense (1) dates from the mid 16th cent.
